question.title: Spring Boot: Default value in application.properties not used when environment variable is missing in Docker
question.body:
I have the following entries in my application.properties:

host=${HOST:http://host.com}
organization.id=${ORGANIZATION_ID:123}
contenttype.id=${CONTENTTYPE_ID:110}

And I inject them like this:

@Configuration
@Getter
@Setter
public class ConfigProperties {

    @Value("${host}")
    private String host;

    @Value("${organization.id}")
    private String organizationId;

    @Value("${contenttype.id}")
    private String contentTypeId;
}

My intention is:

  • If an environment variable (e.g., ORGANIZATION_ID) is provided, use it
  • If not provided, use the default value defined after the colon

When I run the application in Docker without setting ORGANIZATION_ID in the .env file, the application fails to start with this error:

Caused by: org.springframework.util.PlaceholderResolutionException: Could not resolve placeholder 'organization.id' in value "${organization.id}"

This makes it look like the default value from application.properties is being ignored.

Why is Spring Boot not using the default value from application.properties when the environment variable is missing inside Docker, and how can I make Spring use the default when the env var is not defined?

I want Spring to:

  • use the value from the environment if it exists
  • otherwise, use the default from application.properties

But not fail when the env variable is simply not provided.

answers.body:
Change your application.properties to simply be:

host=http://host.com
organization.id=123
contenttype.id=110

Then set your environment variables to be:

HOST=
ORGANIZATION_ID=
CONTENTTYPE_ID=

Spring Boot automatically examines environment variables and uses them as overrides on the following basis:

  1. Swap _ for .
  2. To lower case

Hence env variable ORGANIZATION_ID will automatically override organization.id.

You should try injecting both env value the default value elsewhere, than in application.properties.

Do this:

application.properties

host.default=http://host.com
organization.id.default=123
contenttype.id.default=110

Then inject all directly into ConfigProperties:

@Configuration
@Getter
@Setter
public class ConfigProperties {

    @Value("${HOST:${host.default}}")
    private String host;

    @Value("${ORGANIZATION_ID:${organization.id.default}}")
    private String organizationId;

    @Value("${CONTENTTYPE_ID:${contenttype.id.default}}")
    private String contentTypeId;
}

question_comments.body: Ditch the ${HOST:http://host.com} from your properties file. The HOST environment variable already overrides the host variable from the application.properties. Just write host=http://host.com if provided through the environment it will be overridden automatically. There is no need to make it more complicated then that. Ofcourse that goes for the other properties as well.

there must be something wrong with your setup I've just tested a small SB 3.x here and it works just fine. Initially I thought it was because you are using the values in a @Configuration class but that works fine (though not sure how are you planning on getting those later as it is not a bean). But even then it injects the properties fine with the default (I have to qualify a string bean with the property so I could get in the controller class).
Which version of Spring boot are you using?

Does this setup work without Docker? You don't need to manually set the fallback properties yourself: Spring Boot automatically sets properties from environment variables without you doing anything special. (I've had good results using @ConfigurationProperties classes instead of manual @Value bindings, especially for testing.)

79843056.body: Where did I say you didn't. The question was about when using ENV variables it should use it, if not they should use default values. Your proposed solution doesn't work with missing ENV variables it will disable startup of the application with an error.
@M.Deinum Where did I ever say NOT to use the environment variables?!?
This wouldn't even work without specifying the environment variables. As it would break at startup when loading the application.properties.
